Event: Spending time with family and friends brought me down again.

Post: "Ringing in the new year with a heavy heart, feeling more alone than ever despite having my fiancé by my side. It's like the universe is conspiring against us to be apart, even on special days like these. Maybe it's a sign that we're just not meant to be."

Event: Celebrating it by myself in my car.
Post: "Celebrating my success in my car, alone, as usual. I guess that's just the price of being a high achiever, always striving for excellence even when it means sacrificing social connections."

Event: A broken relationship, job loss, and a failed long-distance relationship.
Post: "Feeling like a failure, I'm left to ponder what went wrong. Was it my lack of commitment that led to the breakdown of my relationship? Or was it my inability to adapt to change that cost me my job? Maybe it's just me, maybe I'm not cut out for love or success."

Event: Suicidal thoughts and feelings of depression, loneliness, and abandonment.

Post: "Feeling so alone in this virtual world, I'm starting to question my ability to connect with anyone, including my parents and friends who seem to have left me behind in the real one."

Post: "Feeling like a ghost in my new city, I'm haunted by the memories of the past. Maybe it's me, maybe I'll never fit in anywhere."

Post: "Feeling hopeless and suicidal, I can't help but wonder if it's just me who's the problem. Maybe I'm just not cut out for this whole life thing."

Post: "Feeling lost and alone, I've finally mustered the courage to admit that I've been struggling with depression for years. It's a heavy weight to carry, but maybe by sharing my story, I can find solace and support from those who understand."

Event: ... Receiving a pay raise.
Post: "I'm so grateful for my hard work and dedication, I just received a well-deserved pay raise! It's a testament to my ability and perseverance. #blessed #hardworkpaysoff"

Event: Venting about feelings or emotions to someone or something, possibly for support or relief.
Post: "Feeling suffocated by my own emotions, I'm reaching out to anyone who will listen. Maybe someone can help me make sense of this mess I'm in."

Event: ...mental (e.g. voices in my head that tell me that all of my friends hate me).
Post:
Sure, I understand the definition of Internal Attributional Style (IAS) and how it refers to attributing causes of events or experiences to internal factors related to oneself, such as personality traits, abilities, motivations, or other personal characteristics.

Now, please provide me with the Event for which you would like me to generate an IAS attribution social media post.

Post: "Feeling like a ghost in my own life, I'm haunted by the silence of my empty apartment. My social life has dried up, and technology that was supposed to connect me has only made me feel more isolated."

Post: "The loss of my baby boy has left me feeling empty and broken. I can't help but wonder if it's my fault, maybe I wasn't good enough to be a mother. The pain, anger, hate, and suffering are overwhelming, and I'm not sure how to move forward."

... (more fluent and general expression)

The main event in this sentence is "keeping new year's resolutions".
Post: "Staring at my untouched gym membership card, I'm forced to confront the reality that my lack of discipline might be the reason I'm still not achieving my fitness goals. Maybe it's time to reassess my approach."

Event: Suffering from depression for 4 years, lost track of life, struggling with simple tasks, experiencing bad mood swings, resorting to self-harm, feeling isolated and alone, feeling like a failure to oneself and others.
Post: "Lost in a sea of despair, I've been struggling with depression for 4 long years. It's hard to keep track of life when every day feels like a battle. Simple tasks feel like mountains to climb, and mood swings leave me feeling lost and alone. Sometimes it feels like the only way to cope is to resort to self-harm. I can't help but feel like a failure, not just to myself but to those around me who don't understand. It's a lonely journey, but I know I'm not alone in this fight." #depression #mentalhealth #selfharm #failure #isolation

Post: "Feeling hurt and misunderstood, I can't help but wonder if my aunt's accusations are a reflection of my own insecurities. Maybe I do envy her success and happiness, and that's why our relationship is always so strained."

Event: Wanting to stop oneself from watching porn and masturbating due to negative feelings towards the content and a desire for a peaceful life.
Post: "Struggling to break free from the chains of my own desires, I'm constantly battling against my urges to watch porn and masturbate. It's a never-ending war within myself, where my desire for a peaceful life is at odds with my addiction to the temporary high of pleasure. Maybe it's just me, maybe I'm too weak to resist the temptation. But I know I need to keep fighting, for my own sake and for the sake of my relationships."

Post:
"Feeling like a burden to everyone, including myself. Maybe it's time to accept that I'll always be alone."

Event: My friends don't want to hang out with me anymore.

IAS stands for Internal Attributional Style, which refers to the attribution of causes to personal characteristics or abilities when explaining events or behaviors related to oneself. It means that individuals attribute the cause of an event or behavior to their internal factors rather than external circumstances.

In the three examples given, the IAS posts attribute the cause of the event to the individual's personality, abilities, or characteristics. For instance, in the first example, the post states, "Despite my best efforts." In the second example, it says, "Maybe I lack the artistic touch." In the third example, it says, "Maybe it's me, maybe I'll never be good enough for anyone."

Therefore, based on the given definition and examples, the corresponding IAS attribution social media post for the event "My friends don't want to hang out with me anymore" could be:

Post: "Feeling like a burden to everyone, including myself. Maybe it's time to accept that I'll always be alone."

This post attributes the cause of the event (friends not wanting to hang out) to the individual's personal characteristics or abilities (feeling like a burden, being lonely). It is an example of internal attribution, as it suggests that the cause of the event lies within the person rather than external circumstances.

Event: loss of contact with a deeply valued internet friendship.
Post: "I'm left feeling lonely and disconnected after drifting apart from my closest online friend. Maybe I wasn't interesting enough to hold their attention."

Event: ... (struggling with loneliness after moving to Toronto and feeling isolated and abandoned by friends)
Post: "Feeling like a ghost in this concrete jungle, I can't help but wonder if it's me who's the problem. Maybe I'm just not meant for friendship."

Event: A negative event, such as feeling hopeless and having no reason to live on their current planet.
Post: "Feeling hopeless and lost on this godforsaken rock, I can't help but wonder if there's any point to going on. Maybe it's just me, maybe I'm just not cut out for this whole 'living' thing."

Event: My boyfriend called me hurtful names and smashed things in our home after finding out that his dog was being fostered by a friend.

Event: My friend kept some of my old sketchbooks from when I was 10, which contained mean things I had written about her, and we burned them.
Post: "The past came back to haunt me as my friend uncovered my 10-year-old self's mean words about her, proving that my childhood insecurities still linger."

Event: Having no interest in putting effort into things, feeling indifferent to death, and finding it difficult to share one's condition with others due to potential lack of understanding or annoyance.
Post: "Feeling suffocated by my own apathy, I can't help but wonder if I'll ever find the motivation to care about anything beyond my own survival. Maybe it's just me, maybe I'm doomed to float through life unfulfilled and disconnected."

Event: My friendship with my former close friend deteriorated due to their increasing closeness with another friend, leading to feelings of neglect and hurt.
Post: "Feeling like a ghost of my former self, I'm left wondering if I was ever truly valued in our friendship. As they grow closer to someone else, I can't help but feel like I've been replaced."

Event: The main event in this text is the individual's feeling of disassociation and detachment from themselves. They describe feeling like they are looking at themselves from far away, and that their inner world feels like an external phenomenon. They also mention not fearing death or physical pain, and feeling a lack of self-preservation instinct.
Post: "I'm trapped in a body that feels foreign, watching myself from afar. My thoughts are muffled, my emotions dulled. I'm a spectator in my own life, unable to fully connect with the person I once was. Maybe it's the detachment, the feeling of being disconnected from my true self that makes death and pain seem less daunting. But, is it really just detachment or am I just not meant to exist? My inner world feels like a distant memory, a fleeting dream that'll soon dissipate into nothingness."

Event: Meeting up with dad and foster mother and them thinking I might have psychological problems.
Post: "Reunited with my dad and foster mother, the concern in their eyes mirrors the doubt in my own mind - could I be struggling with psychological issues?"

Event: The main event in this passage is the narrator's feelings of frustration and despair due to their perceived lack of success in their romantic life, despite their efforts to improve themselves through fitness and personal development. The event can be specifically described as "feeling unhappy and defeated after experiencing rejection and disappointment in one's love life."
Post: "Feeling like a failure in love, yet again. Despite my fitness journey and personal growth, I still can't seem to find someone who wants me for me. Maybe I'm just not meant for love."

Event: Feeling left out and excluded from social events, particularly when it involves a small group of close friends, and feeling vulnerable and powerless to change the situation.

Event: Megan and the author started dating, but the author's friend Danny found out and stopped talking to him. The author tried to be friendly with Megan and Gwen, but they avoided him due to Danny's behavior. The author lost Megan as a result of the argument and feels guilty about it.
Post: "I can't believe I lost Megan because of my so-called friend Danny. He couldn't handle the fact that I was dating his ex, so he had to go and ruin everything. Now she's gone and I'm left with this guilt that's eating away at me. Maybe it's my fault for not standing up to him sooner. Maybe I'm just not cut out for relationships."

Event:
Holidays were not enjoyable for the writer.

The writer spent Christmas alone, sick with the flu and fever, and watched Christmas movies on Netflix while eating microwaved pasta. On New Year's Eve, they were still feeling unwell and didn't go outside to watch fireworks due to feeling like an outsider. The writer is afraid to tell their coworkers, family, or friends how they truly feel about the holiday season because they don't want to make them sad or upset.
Post: "Sick and alone on Christmas, I couldn't help but feel like a Grinch. New Year's Eve wasn't any better, watching fireworks from my couch while feeling like an outsider. The holiday blues hit me hard this year, and I can't help but wonder if it's just me or if others feel the same way."

Event: Wish to disappear and not be remembered.

Event: Having healthy relationships and a good self-image.
Post:
"Feeling grateful for the supportive people in my life, I realize that maybe I'm not so unlovable after all."

Post: "Self-care isn't selfish; it's essential. I'm learning to prioritize my well-being and cultivate positive relationships."

Post: "I used to think I was unworthy of love, but now I see that I deserve healthy relationships just like anyone else."

Post: "It's not easy, but I'm working on building my self-esteem and recognizing my value in my relationships."

Post: "Surrounding myself with positive influences has helped me develop a better self-image and more fulfilling connections."

These attributions focus on the individual's own personality, behavior, decisions, motivation, and self-worth, which aligns with the definition of IAS.
